docs.lead_paragraph: The move by several big health maintenance organizations to end their Medicare coverage in counties where they are losing money should come as no surprise. In their headlong rush to capture part of the huge Medicare market of 38 million Americans, many H.M.O.'s have made inaccurate financial projections and now realize they cannot provide comprehensive care at the cost they expected. Some 400,000 Medicare beneficiaries whose insurers are therefore cutting them loose will now have to find another H.M.O. or go into the traditional fee-for-service Medicare program. Managed care has now become a fact of life for more than 80 percent of Americans covered by private insurance. But it is still quite new in the Government-funded Medicare world where only 17 percent of beneficiaries are enrolled in H.M.O.'s and the rest are still in fee-for-service Medicare. Industry shake-outs will probably continue as more of the Medicare population moves into managed care.
docs.abstract: Editorial on moves by several big health maintenance organizations to end their Medicare coverage in counties where they are losing money; questions how long remaining plans will be able to offer prescription drug benefits and lower deductibles that attract elderly (M)d

docs.lead_paragraph: The last time Wendell Williamson drew national attention, it was one January day in 1995. He seemed to come out of nowhere, firing an M-1 rifle on a busy street near the campus of the University of North Carolina, where he was a law student, and killing two men he had never met. The story of the Chapel Hill shootings made headlines for a few days. But at Mr. Williamson's trial, the jury found him not guilty by reason of insanity, accepting his lawyer's argument that he suffered from paranoid schizophrenia and had believed he was saving the world with his random killings.

headline.main: Killer Blames His Therapist, and Jury Agrees

docs.abstract: Jury verdict awarding Wendell Williamson, killer acquitted by reason of insanity, $500,000 because of alleged shortcomings of psychiatrist, Dr Myron B Liptzin, has provoked furor in North Carolina and beyond; Williamson charged Liptzin, who saw him just half dozen times, made incorrect diagnosis, had not explained how seriously ill he was and had not followed up after their sessions ended, eight months before he randomly shot two men in Chapel Hill; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cardinal Health Acquiring Allegiance for $4.5 Billion The wholesale drug distributor Cardinal Health agreed to buy the hospital supply company Allegiance for $4.5 billion in stock and assume $890 million of its debt.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a primary-care doctor who has worked within the health maintenance organization system, I have become familiar with the misplaced anger expressed by patients toward their doctors because they feel they have been denied care or because their care has been delayed (front page, Oct. 5).
docs.abstract: Dr G Michael Roybal letter says patients do not realize that main force driving cost of health care is not doctors or HMOs but those who finance health are plans: employers and Government (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With temporary financing of the Government due to expire at midnight on Friday, Republican leaders met tonight with White House officials in their first high-level effort to resolve a dozen crucial spending issues and avoid a Government shutdown. The unresolved issues include financing for the International Monetary Fund, how to conduct the 2000 census, and billions of dollars in extra spending for items that the Administration deems emergencies, like the peacekeeping mission in Bosnia, the year 2000 computer bug and disaster relief for farmers.

headline.main: Clinton's Aides and G.O.P. Try to Resolve Budget Issues

docs.abstract: Republican Congressional leaders Speaker Newt Gingrich, Sen Trent Lott and Rep Dick Armey meet with Clinton Administration officials Erskine B Bowles, John D Podesta and Lawrence Stein in first high-level effort to resolve dozen key spending issues and avoid Government shutdown; House leaders strip contentious unrelated provisions from bill that finances Treasury Department and Postal Service and bill is approved, 294-106, with strong support from Democrats; Rep Nita M Lowey scores deletion of contraceptive coverage for female Federal employees; hopes Clinton will insist measure be part of final package; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton plans to announce several steps this week to help Medicare beneficiaries being dropped from health maintenance organizations and is determined to halt the exodus of H.M.O.'s from the program, White House officials said today. The officials said Mr. Clinton was surprised to learn that dozens of H.M.O.'s were scaling back their Medicare operations, in part because costs were higher and Medicare payments lower than they had expected.

headline.main: Clinton Plans To Intervene As H.M.O's Exit Medicare

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration says Pres Clinton will announce steps to help Medicare beneficiaries being dropped from health maintenance organizations and is determined to halt HMO exodus from program; says it underestimated number of HMOs that would withdraw; some members of Congress report being inundated with calls from Medicare beneficiaries being dropped by HMOs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last spring, Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republican leaders in the House promised representatives from the Christian Coalition that Congress would end what the conservatives call partial-birth abortion, eliminate financing for the National Endowment for the Arts and work for a constitutional amendment to permit prayer in public schools. So much for promises. Not one of the measures was adopted. Neither was much else of consequence this year in one of the least productive sessions of Congress in memory.

headline.main: Washington Talk; Congress Leaves Its Promises From Spring Largely Unfulfilled

docs.abstract: Congress has achieved little of consequence this year in one of its least productive sessions in memory; Republicans and Democrats have failed to pass much of their legislative agendas; public apparently favors low Congressional productivity, giving Congress far higher approval rating than in recent years when it passed major bills (M)
